title:
Access to artemisinin-based anti-malarial
treatment and its related factors in rural Tanzania
authors: Khatib RA, Selemani M, Mrisho GA, Masanja IM, Amuri M, Njozi MH, Kajungu D, Kuepfer I, Abdulla SM, de Savigny D
location: Kilombero-Ulanga and Rufiji Districts in Tanzania
intervention: Social marketing of ACTs and private and accredited drug dispensing outlets (ADDOs) were implemented in certain districts
outcomes-bf: No significance  difference in 24 hour access to ACT outlets for households experiencing fever between a district with ADDOs plus  social marketing and one without.

title: Narrowing the treatment gap with equitable access: Mid-term outcomes of a community case management program in Cameroon
authors: Littrell M, Moukam LV, Libite R, Youmba JC, Baugh G
intervention:
Community case management for childhood ilnesses. CCM package provided
community-based diagnosis, treatment and referral for suspected
malaria with artemisinin combination therapy (ACT)
and diarrheal disease with ORS and zinc through community health workers (PSI)
outcomes-bf:
Awareness, access and attitudes towards CHW
services among caregivers improved with intervention
outcomes-behavior:
Children living in intervention vs comparison
areas were significantly more likely to receive treatment
at a public health facility or through a CHW for fever  and diarrhoea

Appropriate treatment was significantly higher among children
in intervention vs comparison areas including: antimalarial
treatment for fever , ACT
for fever , ORS for
diarrhoea and zinc for
diarrhoea

title: Improvements in access to malaria treatment in Tanzania following community, retail sector and health facility interventions: A user perspective
authors: Alba S, Dillip A, Hetzel MW, Mayumana I, Mshana C, Makemba A, Alexander M, Obrist B, Schulze A, Kessy F, Mshinda H, Lengeler C
population: Treatment-seeking survey of people who had suffered a fever case in  the previous 14 days
intervention: Social marketing for improved treatment seeking
outcomes-bf:
Improvements in understanding causes of malaria (from 62% to 84%); higher treatment coverage
with anti-malarials (86% to 96%)
outcomes-behavior: Increases in health facility attendance as first treatment option for patients older than five years (27% to 52%);  more timely use of anti-malarials (80% to 93-97% treatments taken within 24 hrs).

title:
Household ownership and use of insecticide treated nets among target groups after implementation of a national voucher programme in the United Republic of Tanzania:
Plausibility study using three annual cross sectional household surveys
authors: Hanson K, Marchant T, Nathan R, Mponda H, Jones C, Bruce J, Mshinda H, Schellenberg JA
intervention: Social marketing combined with the National Voucher Scheme targeting mothers of young children at antenatal clinics
outcomes-bf: ITN ownership increased from 18% to 36%
outcomes-behavior: Among infants under 1 year of age, use of an ITN increased from 16% to 34%

title:
Distribution systems of insecticide-treated bed nets for
malaria control in rural Burkina Faso: Cluster-
randomized controlled trial
authors: Müller O, De Allegri M, Becher H, Tiendrebogo J, Beiersmann C, Ye M, Kouyate B, Sie A, Jahn A
intervention: Subsidized ITN distribution through social marketing with or without free ITN distribution (free distribution took place through antenatal clinics)
outcomes-bf: ITN ownership increased in SM with free distribution areas more than in SM only areas from  baseline  to  follow-up
outcomes-behavior: Increases in Bednet use in previous night was similarly higher in both groups from baseline to follow-up; use among pregnant women and children under five increased in SM with free distribution from   44% to 50% and in SM only from 37% to 44%.

title:
Health microinsurance, social marketing, and
disease prevention: Perspectives from the field
authors: McCord J,  Rivers K
location: Kisiizi and Ishaka in southwestern Uganda
population: Microinsurance organization clients over the age  of 18
intervention: Comparison of health microinsurance organization clients who only had basic health education  verus those exposed to social marketing of SmartNet ITN
outcomes-bf: knowledge, perceptions, barriers, sources of information; perceptions of ITNs were  more positive and rates  of ownership were higher among those exposed to social marketing
smbc: 4: Behavior, Customer orientation, Theory, Method mix

title: The impact of a hybrid social marketing intervention on inequities in access, ownership and use of insecticide-treated nets
authors: Agha S, Van Rossem R, Stallworthy G, Kusanthan T
population: Household survey of men and women ages 15-49
intervention: ITN subsidy  and social marketing intervention  to increase knowledge,  access, and use of ITNs as part of the  Roll Back Malaria Campain. Distribution was through public health facilities.
outcomes-bf: Knowledge of malaria and ITNs, access to ITNs, beliefs about malaria protection, ownership (number of ITNs in  the household)
outcomes-behavior: Usage of  ITNs (respondent usually sleeps under a net)
smbc: 7: Customer orientation, Behavior, Insight, Exchange, Competition, Segmentation, Methods  mix

title: Lessons learned from bednet distribution in Central Mozambique
authors: Brentlinger PE
intervention: Commericial shopkeepers and community leaders were trained to  promote and sell ITNs in 19 sites between 2000-2004
outcomes-bf: ITN ownership;

title:
Sustained high coverage of insecticide-treated bednets through
combined catch-up and keep-up strategies
authors: Grabowsky M, Nobiya T, Selanikio J
population: Households with at least one child less than 5 years of age
intervention:
Mass, free distribution (Catch-up) of insecticide-treated bednets (ITNs) during measles
vaccination campaigns, followed by antenatal clinic-based social marketing for routine Keep-up on ITN coverage and use
outcomes-bf:
95.7% of children slept in a household that had a net, 86.1% slept in a household that had a campaign
net
outcomes-behavior: 59.6% of children slept under an ITN

title:
Comparison of coverage with insecticide-treated nets in a
Tanzanian town and villages where nets and insecticide are either marketed or provided free of charge
authors: Maxwell CA, Rwegoshora RT,  Magesa SM, Curtis CF
population: Household survey of men and women
intervention: Social marketing of ITNs and insecticide
outcomes-bf: % of households that purchased a net, % of households with  intact treated nexts
outcomes-behavior: % of households reporting usage in urban and rural areas that had social marketing were compared to areas with free distribution

title: Socially marketed insecticide-treated nets effectively reduce Plasmodium infection and anaemia among children in urban Malawi
authors: Mathanga DP, Campbell CH, Taylor TE, Barlow R, Wilson ML
intervention: ITN social marketing by PSI
outcomes-bf: Knowledge of ITNs
outcomes-behavior: 42% of children reported ITN use the previous night
outcomes-health: 42% of children reported ITN use the previous night

title: Reduction of childhood malaria by social marketing of insecticide-treated nets: A case-control study of effectiveness in Malawi
authors: Mathanga DP, Campbell CH, Taylor TE, Barlow R, Wilson ML
journal: The American journal of tropical medicine and hygiene, 2005, 73(3): 622-625
population: Case-control study of children under  age 5 with history of fever within last 48 hours
intervention: ITN social marketing (PSI)
outcomes-bf: ITN coverage
outcomes-health:
Individual effectiveness of ITN use was 40% (95% confidence interval [CI] 10–60%) when cases were
compared with clinic controls and 50% (95% CI 0–60%) in comparison with community controls; 1,480
malaria cases averted by the intervention in a population of 15,000 children

title: Spatial effects of the social marketing of insecticide-treated nets on malaria morbidity
authors: Abdulla S, Gemperli A, Mukasa O, Armstrong Schellenberg JR, Lengeler C, Vounatsou P, Smith T
intervention: Social marketing of ITNs
outcomes-bf: Coverage, distribution pattern and resultant spatial effects
outcomes-behavior: Percent of children using a treated net
outcomes-health: Prevalence of parasitaemia, mild anaemia (Hb <11 g/dl) and moderate/severe anaemia (Hb <8 g/dl) in children under five; children living in areas of moderately high ITN coverage were

title:
The economics of social marketing: The case of
mosquito nets in Tanzania
authors: Kikumbih N, Hanson K, Mills A, Mponda H, Schellenberg JA
population: Household survey of men and women
intervention: Kilombero and Ulanga insecticide-treated net (KINET) project used social marketing to  promote Zuia  Mbu nets and insecticide treatment kits
outcomes-bf: Knowledge  about ITNS and insecticide treatment, coverage (proportion of households with at least one net)
outcomes-health: About half as likely to have moderate/severe anaemia
smbc: 4: Customer orientation, Behavior, Segmentation, Methods mix

title:
Mosquito nets and the poor: Can social marketing redress
inequities in access?
authors: Nathan R, Masanja H, Mshinda H, Schellenberg JA, de Savigny D, Lengeler C, Tanner M, Victora CG
intervention: Social marketing of treated nets over three year period
outcomes-bf: Ownership  increased 37% to 73%; among poorest households ownership of at least one net  increased 20% to 54%
smbc: 5: Customer orientation, Insight, Competition, Segmentation, Methods mix

title: Insecticide-treated bednet use, anaemia, and malaria parasitaemia in Blantyre District, Malawi
authors: Holtz TH, Marum LH, Mkandala C, Chizani N, Roberts JM, Macheso A, Parise ME, Kachur SP
population: Households with at least one child less than 5 years of age
intervention: Social marketing of ITNs by PSI
outcomes-bf:
Bednet ownership was low
(20.5% of households)
outcomes-behavior: Only 3.3% of rural children under 5 had slept under a net the previous night, compared
outcomes-health: Health: rural children under 5 in households without nets experienced a statistically significant higher prevalence of malaria parasitaemia [RR  4.9] than children in households with at least one bednet
smbc: 6: Behavior, Customer orientation, Insight, Exchange, Segmentation, Methods mix

title: Impact of malaria morbidity of a programme supplying insecticide treated nets in children aged under 2 years in Tanzania: Community cross sectional study
authors: Abdulla S, Schellenberg JA, Nathan R, Mukasa O, Marchant T, Smith T, Tanner M, Lengeler C
intervention: Social marketing of ITNs and insecticide
outcomes-bf: Net ownership of treated nets increased 10% to 61%
outcomes-health: Prevalence  of parasitemia and haemoglobin levels; prevalence  of anemia  decreased from  49% to 26%; Treated nets had a protective efficacy of 62% on prevalence of parasitaemia and of 63% on anaemia.

title: Effect of large-scale social marketing of insecticide-treated nets on child survival in rural Tanzania
authors: Schellenberg JR, Abdulla S, Nathan R, Mukasa O, Marchant TJ, Kikumbih N, Mushi AK, Mponda H, Minja H, Mshinda H, Tanner M, Lengeler C
location: Kilombero and Ulanga Districts in  southwestern Tanzania
population: Case-control study among children age 1 month to 4 years and a demographic surveillance system survey of households
intervention: ITN social marketing
outcomes-bf:
Insecticide-treated net coverage of infants in the study area rose from less than 10% at baseline to more than
50% 3 years later.
outcomes-health: 18 months after launching, 46% of 312 families with children aged under 5 years reported that their children were sleeping under treated nets
smbc: 6: Behavior, Customer orientation, Insight, Exchange, Segmentation, Methods mix

title:
Socially-marketed rapid diagnostic tests and ACT
in the private sector: Ten years of experience in
Cambodia
authors: Yeung S, Patouillard E, Allen H, Socheat D
intervention: Social  marketing of RDTs and ACT
outcomes-bf: Providers knowledge of RDTS and ACT, product availablity, sales/selling price; Consumer awareness of RDTS and ACT
outcomes-behavior: 18 months after launching, 46% of 312 families with children aged under 5 years reported that their children were sleeping under treated nets
smbc: 7: Behavior, Customer orientation,  Insight, Exchange, Competition, Segmentation, Methods mix

title: KINET: A social marketing programme of treated nets and net treatment for malaria control in Tanzania, with evaluation of child health and long-term survival
authors: Schellenberg JR, Abdulla S, Minja H, Nathan R, Mukasa O, Marchant T, Mponda H, Kikumbih N, Lyimo E, Manchester T, Tanner M, Lengeler C
journal: Trans R Soc Trop Med Hyg, 1999,  93(3): 225-31
location: Kilombero and Ulanga Districts in  southwestern Tanzania
intervention: ITN and insecticide social marketing
outcomes-bf: 24% of households had at least one treated net
outcomes-behavior: 18 months after launching, 46% of 312 families with children aged under 5 years reported that their children were sleeping under treated nets
smbc: 6: Behavior, Customer orientation, Insight, Exchange, Segmentation, Methods mix
